reviewText:
This remake isn't for everybody, but it's a very good release for a certain set of players, which includes me.

As everyone knows, only the Restoration of Erathia has been remastered. The expansions are not available. People who want to download and play custom maps are not going to want HoMM 3 HD Edition, because most custom maps require the expansions to play.

So what exactly do I like about it?

I've never been so devoted to playing any HoMM game that I spend all my time with it. I have a lot of other games I like to play. When I do feel like playing HoMM, I will pick a version and spend a few weeks or a few months playing with it. Then, I move on to the next game.

So, I guess you could call me a casual" HoMM player
date: and I only am interested in single player mode. By the time I finish all the campaigns in Restoration of Erathia
recommended: I am ready to move on to another game. So
hoursPlayed: I might as well enjoy the Restoration of Erathia campaign with the best available graphics and remastering.\n\nI also own the GoG.com complete version
voteText: with the HD mod. I find that I like the new HD version better
helpfulPercent: especially since it doesn't shrink the interface so small
votesHelpful: and doesn't zoom out so far. I play on an 82" television screen
votesTotal: and the remastered character sprites are noticeably sharper to me than in the HD mod on the GoG.com version.\n\nIf I still feel like playing Blade of Armageddon and other expansions or downloaded custom maps after I finish Restoration of Erathia
votesFunny: I can move to the GoG.com with HD mod version and continue playing
commentsCount: although I will miss the improvements from the new HD version.\n\nIt doesn't have to be an either-or between the two versions. It can be a both-and. I will use the new version to play Restoration of Erathia
column16: and enjoy lighting up the achievements and having the Steam support. Then I will switch to the other version if I feel like continuing.\n\nI've had no problems with stability issues nor found any bugs
column17: either.\n\nI think my $15 was well-spent. That's less than the price of a home-delivered pizza dinner
column18: and I'm getting weeks worth of much-enjoyed entertainment hours out of it."

reviewText:
Ok, so, I know I've only played the HD version for a short while, but bear in mind I have wasted thousands of hours on the original. Also at the time of writing this review it's on the latest Humble Bundle, so if you want a lot of Might and Magic, that's where to grab it -very- cheap, and it is definitely well worth it.

I recommend this game.
At the full price? No, definitely not. But on offer? Sure, why not.

What are the noticeable differences?
Models -are- better, I'm not sure if people are just wearing nostalgia-goggles but I can see a clear difference. Enough for me to see there was an improvement.
Text is far clearer, overall It just looks... neater. More crisp, the entire game does. While some people like the looks of the original (as do I) I see nothing wrong with an updated version. And yes you can get HD packs with Mods, but some people might not trust mods, etc.


Also, one thing I've seen throughout a boat-load of reviews is people complaining they took Conflux away (The elemental nation) those who think that clearly don't remember that faction was an Expansion. It was not in the original game, not even the creatures were if I recall correctly. I'm hoping they release the updated expansions though, that's when It'll be worth your hard-earned money.

What is HoMM?
Some people might have never even heard of this game, and most of the reviews I've seen are just pointing out the differences and not explaining what the actual game is.

Heroes of Might and Magic III is a turn-based Fantasy strategy game. You play a faction of your choice (Or depending on the scenario a specific one) based on many different mythological fantasies.

First up is the Castle. These are the humans of the game, based on high-fantasy humanity, Griffins, Pikemen, Swordsman, Knights, etc. Fairly basic, not too much fantasy there, but still a fun game.

Fortress: This is a Swamp-based faction, such as Lizard men, Dragonfly, Gorgon and even Hydra. Most of these creatures all follow that theme.

Dungeon: Pretty much what it says on the box. Beholders, Minotaur, Black Dragon, Beholders, Naga, the things you can expect in a higher-fantasy underground based faction.

Rampart: The true 'high fantasy' faction, in my eyes. Dwarves, Elves, Unicorn, Centaur. These are the woodland creatures which are staple in nearly all high fantasy settings.

Tower: This is the 'magical' faction, so to speak. Magi, Animated Golem, Gargoyles and Genie are the sort of units you'll expect from here.

Necropolis: Much like the dungeon, it's self explanatory. Skeletons, Undead, Lich, Vampires, etc. The darkest of the factions focused on the risen dead.

The game is played on an 'overhead map' where you control a hero with a certain set of movement, exploring the map and fighting monsters. Capturing things like Gold Mines and Crystal mines will generate those resources each turn (very valuable). The aim of the game is to simply beat your enemy in most scenarios. Although there are some specific campaign levels and scenarios where you have to achieve a certain objective, such as Kill X, take Y or find Z.

Upon engaging an enemy you effectively zoom into a turn-based battlefield where your units are on one side and the enemy's are on the other. It's your job to command your troops (Each has specific health, attack, etc) and simply kill all the enemy (Unless they retreat)

Each type of unit will stack into one group unless you split them and choose otherwise. (For example you can have a near unlimited amount of units in a single stack as long as they are the same troop, EG. 14 Swordsman)

The way you recruit units is by going into your cities and Purchasing the required buildings. You may only build one a turn so you should think things through before you buy them. For example, the game revolves around a weekly/monthly system, where each turn is one day. At the start of the week you can buy a fresh set of recruited troops. So it's often best on the later days of the week to either buy a building that unlocks new troops, or purchase something that increases the amount of men you generate per week, such as the Griffon Bastion in the Castle faction (Generates extra griffon a week).


In conclusion it's a fairly decent game, It has it's problems now as it also had it's problems then, is it worth the full price they're asking? No, not in my opinion. But if you can grab it on offer? Yeah, I'd say it's worth it. Even more so if you use Steam as your sole games platform. As stated at the top at the time of writing this review you can pick it, and many many more Might and Magic games up on the Humble Bundle.

reviewText:
For the younger generations of gamers you might not quite grasp or appreciate the beauty that was HoMM3, however for me this game brings back Nostalgia not just in the gameplay but the reminscent LAN parties or the day spent playing a game with a friend on multiplayer hotseat while watching movies and enjoying yourself.  There is a beautiful simplicity to being able to both plot out your movements, use strategy in both how you build your towns, how you control your armies, and the combat system, but to also be able to do this while in a relaxed and casual atmosphere.

Sure there is the downside that this game does not include all of the great expansions to HoMM3 and sure you can get those if you buy the complete game on GoG, but at the end of the day multiplayer through steam is just the easiest way to enjoy this game without any headaches and additional 3rd party software.  The random map generator may not be at your disposal here, but what is, is one of the best games ever made in it's original format, remastered with the same look and feel that we all loved, just with the ability to play it full screen with today's graphic standards.

I absolutely love the game and welcome everyone to try it out, if you are ever looking for someone to play some multiplayer with I'll definitely be available for a game.

reviewText:
You know what's really sad.. in 1999 3DO released Heroes of Might and Magic III. I played that game for _years_. Not only have I been playing it since I was around 9 years old, I've probably put thousands of hours into it altogether.

That said, I have never seen a single bug. I'm not saying that they don't exist, but they sure as hell were not obvious. The game was so polished that to this day it remains the iconic and definitive version of the HOMM series.

As we know, Ubisoft has done a remake of the game in HD. They claim to have repolished some 20k+ assets. I've played about 11 hours (according to steam) and in those 11 hours have noticed blatant, unacceptable, almost laughable bugs. Its so amazing what damage can be done to a product when the motive behind producing it is money, instead of the gratification of doing a good job and being proud of what you get to share with people.

Example bugs:
1. I went to move my battle dwarf, and instead of the battle dwarf moving sound, it played the death sound from an enemy unit I recently killed, _every_ _single_ _step_. And it wasn't just my dwarf! When the enemy moved his it played the same sound! Its as if the data got mixed up somehow. Maybe a dangling pointer? In any case, certainly no excuse for it considering the original never exposed an issue like that.

2. These HD" ground clutter sprites frequently bug out and cause the grid to be able to be highlighted and its color change to that of a valid state
date: as if you could move there. The old version correctly changed to the "cannot move there" cursor - every time.\n\n3. The game flat out stops when it receives WM_KILLFOCUS from the Windows message pump. Not "stops rendering" or "stops audio". I mean the game stops. It pauses everything. So you can't end your turn and do something else while the AI runs their turn. You can't even click on your castle and alt tab out to load a youtube video or something. Granted
hoursPlayed:
but totally unnecessary change.

4.Arbitrary extremely weird glitches like a unit just jumping places for no reason and moving back.

It just overall feels unpolished

reviewText:
Okay, let's get the obvious criticism out of the way: you can buy HOMM 3 plus all expansion packs from GOG for $9.99, which is around £6-£7 depending on the exchange rate. The GOG pack comes with all expansions and adds the Conflux castle and lots of new creatures, and there is a fan-made HD mod that can bump the resolution up to 4000x4000 for picky players. In contrast, this remastered HD edition of HOMM 3 is just the base game, minus the 'random map' option in Single Player mode - so it seems like a lot less.

I know all this. I agree with those saying it's a no-brainer in terms of cost: for ~£4 less you get more bang for your buck by buying the original versions from GOG. I have done so, and spent many, many, *many* hours cruising my way through Erathia with my boy Theodorus and our army of Iron Golems.

But despite all of the above...I have to say, I really, really like Ubisoft's HD edition, because it looks absolutely gorgeous.  I've only played through half a scenario so far (you might say this is jumping the gun somewhat, but some of the negative reviews already posted are after less than 15 minutes of gameplay so I feel I'm allowed) but I've not encountered any bugs at all, other than the fact I had to prise myself away from the PC to make my dinner.

The gameplay is as smooth as it was in the standard HOMM 3 (none of the jerky movements that shake me out of the action when I replay HOMM 2) but the graphics...look, they're not HD" in the standard version of the word. But they are absolutely lovely and you can tell that a lot of love and effort has gone into the enhancements. Everything is so much clearer
date: and it adds a lot more character to the Hero portraits
recommended: Creature portraits and sprites. HOMM 3 does look sorta fuzzy next to them now! I'm currently playing as Tower
hoursPlayed: my all-time favourite faction in any Heroes game
voteText: and I feel like I'm seeing the Heroes and the Creatures all over again. They feel a lot more expressive.\n\nSo...would I recommend it? Yes. I would. And I really hope that Ubisoft think about converting the expansion packs in future

votesHelpful: full disclosure and all that
votesTotal: I only bought the game because it was £5.99 in the Steam sale and would recommend anyone looking to play it to wait until a) it's at a reduced price - at least in line with GOG - or b) Ubisoft add the expanions
votesFunny: if they ever do.\n\nAnyway
commentsCount: that's enough of that. There's a Stronghold castle across the way with my name on it."

reviewText: You know, most of the people here are giving this version a bad review, and I will have  an opinion in contrast  to them. Now, before you get on the hate wagon, hear me out. I am a diehard heroes fan, I have played them all since the begining and just want to state this. Heroes 3 is off course, my favorite, and I really wanted to see it in HD. For this , I am grateful to Ubisoft that they did it. I like the new sprites and the graphical overhaul , you really can tell the difference especially on a bigger screen. Yes I am aware of the comunity patch too- this version does look better  because of the updated models. Now, could they have done more on these money and gave us the expansions? Definately, and with this I agree with the general consensus, they are stretching it... I would recomend this game on a sale, definately. The HD graphics and sprites do look sweet, for a Heroes 3 fanboy like me it does worth it. I did pay 15 euros and I am happy with my purchase so far. It is a decent price I think for a HD remake - many say is to much, but in the end, it is the producer's work that they put value on -  (they could have included the expansions though-that's my biggest beef with Ubisoft). The GOG version, yes that is very good, I have that version too, I buyed this for the HD overhaul, and in this regard it has not dissapointed me.\n\n@Ubisoft- Guys, I have paid the full 15 euros price on Steam, no keys from other retailers, no sale. My only request to you is this: Please make Armageddon's Blade and Shadow of Death HD too and put a decent price tag on them. I will buy them if you do, and I am sure many Heroes fans will, despite their negative comments here on Steam. It is good to see HD graphics on such a good game, and I am sure many fans agree with me here.

reviewText:
Many people complain about the lack of content, I understand that, but there is a explanation why that is...

Ubisoft weren't the original developers of the game, so the source code (which is required for the expantion packs) is gone. Ubisoft only had the code for the base game, which they polished. I like what they managed to do, the game does have the updated feel to it.

While I doubt this will happen, I hope ubisoft will re-write the code for the expantions, but if they don't- I don't see why the community cant implement the content trough mods.

This review doesnt tell much about the gameplay of the game itself, so I might update the review someday, I just wanted to get the word out that the game aint as bad as people claim it to be- it just lacks the content everyone was used to have.

reviewText:
Not sure about the hate for this remake
In my experience it's not buggy, animation can be but all it requires is the combat animation speed to be increased
This game is timeless and always will be, the HD lifting is superb and breathes life into a game that it borderline too graphically inferior to have a load of play time these days.
Has never crashed or bugged out for me. Online works a treat and the expansions are unnecessary, only way to play this game is with the Archangel on the main title screen and him fighting the Devil on the loading screen, vintage!
If there's one game from the early age of great computer games that deserves a HD remake it's this one. Way and always will be the greatest fantasy game ever made.
Money well spend and would buy again, 10/10

reviewText:
To all those saying this version doesn't have good graphics and the hd patch is the same they are completely wrong. I have both versions and this one has far superior graphics.

What the unofficial hd patch does is blow the map portion up to 1920x1080 so it fills your screen. It doesn't increase the resolution of any of the assets, and probably most irritating to me, it doesn't rescale the UI to match the larger resolution. So yeah, you see a huge area of map all shrunk down, but all the icons and creatures and towns are tiny! I actually had to downsize my res to like 1400 something just so I could read the text without squinting.

The HD remake here on steam is a ton better. It displays in 1920x1080 but it keeps the correct scaling of UI and creatures. And they look really nice, they have been touched up for this edition.

So all these people complaining about price, really you get what you pay for sometimes, or wait for a sale. I got my copy of a humble bundle. Although I do understand missing the expansions, that could be a deal breaker. But just want to put to rest the idea that the hd patch is equal to this remake- it's not at all. This version is comfortable to play and definitely doesn't feel like a 15 year old game.

reviewText:
Let me just start off by saying that f you weren't one of us old schoolers who mastered this game in junior high, you are seriously missing out.  Buy it now (either here or on Gog.com and PLAY IT!)  Now, for those of you that are wondering if this beefed up version is worth the extra money, especially if you have another copy laying around (most especially if that copy includes the expansions).

Well ... that depends.

Are the HD graphics pretty?  Yes, they are.  Is it immediately noticeable when you load the game, like a rabbit-punch to the throat?  Not really.  But if you switch between the two versions, the beauty of the HD really shines through.  I only wish Ubisoft had taken the time to include all the expansions with this release, but I imagine they plan to put them out in the future.

Gameplay improvements?  Nope.  None.  Not that I've been able to ascertain.  There are definitely some major bugs crawling through the programming here, some things are a little messy, and it could use some work.  Do I think these will be resolved soon?  Most likely.

The main reason I decided to buy this game was because my family and I like to play multiplayer together, but can't abide by using the hotseat option (who wants to pass around a heavy gaming laptop or switch seats at a desktop?).  We've tried to play our original copies and our digital copies from Amazon via Gameranger, but my brother's computer was unable to connect and constantly booting him.

Does this new version solve this problem?  Yes, and no.  Yes, we can connect and have successfully played two multiplayer games, but there are also some serious, serious issues.  Whenever we start a new game, we inevitably have to start it four or five times due to disconnects.  I tried to determine if it was a firewall or router issue, but was unable to find a problem on my end.

Also, it would've been amazing if Ubisoft could've made some modern improvements like letting players see each other's gameplay in a multiplayer game.  It's awfully boring to sit with a load screen while your partners fight epic battles that can last ten or more minutes.  There could've been some improvement to the AI - as it's either way too easy or way too hard depending on the map, scenario, etc.  With such a beautiful game put in their lap to begin with, it shouldn't have been too hard to make some improvements, do some balancing with creatures, spells, and heroes, etc.

In short, this game is worth the money if you like to play multiplayer.  If not, then stick to the full version with all expansions - even if it doesn't have the pretty graphics.  The art in the HD version is lovely, but graphics to me are never more important than gameplay.

All in all, it's a pretty decnt classic to have on steam but for the price I suggest you wait till it drops before even considering.

reviewText:
Amazing game, the best in the series in my opinion. The support for high resolutions without tweaking ( I run 3240x1920 ) makes me very happy, as it can be a hassle getting some games to run properly.

voteText: 7 of 33 people (21%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have played this game for literally thousands of hours over the years, and I am happy to say that it is just as much fun now as I was decades ago. Many series connoisseurs consider this one to be the best, and when it comes to fluidity, ease of play and sheer addictiveness, they may be right. A fantasy world bursting with diversity just waiting to be explored paired with quick, satisfying turn-based strategic battles make this one a winner.

This HD version is just what you would expect: sharp, cleaned-up graphics with very little else changed. Be aware that the game has not been optimized for widescreen, so you will see large bars on the left and right of the screen keeping it in its original aspect ratio. Also be aware that you are only getting the original Heroes III release with this and NOT the expansions, Armageddon's Blade and Shadow of Death, the former of which introduces an entire new faction and many units as well as thousands of hours of campaign fun. If you want that, you will have to get Heroes III Complete, available from a number of other reputable sellers.

In summary, if you have never played Heroes III before, want to give it a try and insist on HD visuals, pick this one up. I would not recommend it to those who already have Heroes III Complete, as the graphics upgrade is very small and does not make much of a difference to the experience, at least to me. If you prefer content over a small graphics boost, consider purchasing Heroes III Complete, which is a much greater experience on many levels and is available for this same price or less.

reviewText:
(This review reflects the game itself, be it purchased in 1999 or now. It does not cover the actions of, or my opinions on Ubisoft)

Heroes of Might & Magic III is nothing short of magnificent.

It is the one game I always come back to, and always install on every computer I own. Since its release in 1999 it quickly became a family favorite, and to this day we still start up large hot seat games at family gatherings (though we rarely finish them). I have sunk countless hours into this game, and I am still not bored with it. I am still excited by exploring the map, I still love the artwork and unique factions, and the music still inspires awe and wonder. As a result I was certainly excited to see it on Steam. Heads up though, this is version does not yet have the expansions, but will offer multiplayer support!
---------

Everything about this game works exceptionaly well.

-Despite being near 16 years old the aesthetic of the game is still very beautiful and appealing. Which makes exploring maps and playing your favorite factions that much more enjoyable.

- The Factions are well balanced and delightfully unique. Each having their own awesome theme and excellent musical scores. Despite haveing played it for so long I am still somewhat of a casual player, so if you talked with some of the pros they could better critique the faction ballance. But I do know enough to say this: To Hell with Conflux! Oh, and I love Fortress and Castle dearly!

- The Music is fantastic. Every biome, faction, and item on the map has its own music or soudbyte which plays on or in proximity to the location. As your hero moves across the map the music and ambient sound changes to fit your location. This promotes a wonderful atmosphere while exploring, and makes for a very enjoyable experience. Each of the factions have their own score crafted for them to fit their themes, and in a text review, I will not be able to do them justice. If you want a taste then I suggest that you briefly look up the theme music for Fortress (my favorite), Stronghold, and Necropolis. I should mention before ending this note that the music was the work of Paul Romero who I salute for his dedication and hardwork which made Heroes III that much better!

-The game mechanics and overall design is solid and intuitive. I have introduced the game to many friends and all of them took the game quickly. It was built upon the framework set up in Heroes 1 and 2, and it refined the system found in those games. It is clear that a lot of thought went into crafting this title.

-----------------

I adore this game. Everything about it is as close to flawless as anygame can aspire to be. I would like to think it is a labor of love, and it really shows. And for those who are lead to doubt by its age, it aged well. To this day there is little I could criticize as a result of the passing of time. The Music is fantastic, and the art is still beautiful.

I understand that I may not have articulated my thoughts very well, so let me end with this point. The HOMM series is approacing seven titles now. And Heroes III is still considered by the grand majority of fans to be the undisputed champion. Most of the other games are also quite good, but they just cannot quite compare to the greatness achieved by Heroes III. It has almost become something of a problem for later releases in the series. Despite their own merits and achievments, the other games are still measured against Heroes III, and as a result are judged by it. But I do recommend you give the other games a try as well.

Heroes III is the Titan of the Heroes series, and for good reason. It is a masterpiece, and still stands amongst the greatest turn based stradegy games ever made.

Long Live the King!

My thoughts...

Pros:
1. The game looks heaps better!

Cons:
1. Does not come with expansion (no extra maps, no Conflux, no random map generator)

I am having fun on this game and so would recommend it. I think the majority of people, including me to a degree expected more completeness. I am really hoping they include more maps/the expansion. It would really suck if we had to buy downloadable content.

I am having fun playing this classic childhood game

reviewText:
Lets put this straight. This is only Restoration of Erathia, so no AB content, no SoD content. But lets forget about it for a while.
I was around 7 or 8 years old when my sister gave me heroes 3. I still remember amazement that came with buying first Magog, succesful completion of Key to Victory, cheating (yes, i did it! for some time). It became my favourite game immediately.
And now, it came back. With a bit of diffrence.
Title says it's HD. To be honest, I haven't noticed much change at first - some units had more details, everything looked a bith more smooth - but devs allowed players to decide if they want to see the game in HD or as it was when it firstly came out. And then, you can see how much they did. Job well done.
Apart of graphics, nothing has been changed in game mechanics - and bless the devs. So if you are H3 Veteran, and would love to see RoE in new clothes - buy it. If you have only heard of H3 - buying this game would be the best you could do - you just wouldn't miss Addons content - game is great even without them.
One thing i'd love to know - will addons be relased? And will they be free, or (knowing Ubi) relased as paid DLCs?

reviewText:
Update:  I changed my review from negative to positive after 2 hours of play.  You can see the old review below.  The music is the same between original and HD release.  There are 4 combat soundtracks, and 3 is the annoying one.  It isn't that annoying if the sound is turned down some.  Once I had similar sound levels between computers, they sounded identical.  While I haven't seen all units yet, the only one that I consider worse than the original is the pikeman.  The rest seem fine to me.

Here is the old review:
This is my first impression after playing for 20 minutes.  I have a KVM setup so I can switch between the old version on a Windows XP machine, and the new version on Windows 7, viewing both on the same monitor.

My first impression was positive.  The initial screens looked better and more crisp.  The color palette is the same, bright colors that made the original artwork charming.  I then navigated to the combat screen, and that is where I went to a negative rating for the game.  The art for the pikeman was pretty bad.  The archer was ok, and I didn't notice anything glaringly bad about the enemies I was facing.

What I found really annoying was the combat music.  On the original version, the music had deeper tones and a good pace.  On the new version, it was this annoying high pitched instrument (flute maybe?).  The pace seemed slightly faster too, making me feel agitated.  Considering that you hear the combat music over and over in this game, bad music can get very annoying.  I am trying to decide if the newer graphics are worth the bad music.  I think my initial feeling is that I would rather play the original.

On the positive, this is supported for Windows 7, so if my XP machine dies, at least I have an option to continue playing it.

P.S.  The intro video did not appear updated.  I am not surprised, as it would have been a major undertaking for little value.

reviewText:
disregard pretty much every negative review on here. Everyone is all upset about the game only including the original base game.

It never stated that it included anything else, you shouldn't negatively review a product because it doesn't have something it never said it had

They are also upset that it didn't include a map generator, kinda understand, and it'd be nice if they brought it back, however

Random Map Generator SUCKED, always has, always will, what keeps Heroes 3, map wise, alive, is people making maps, not just playing horrible generated maps that are unbalanced and unimaganitive. There IS a map maker in this game, if you want to play custom maps, make your own. If you don't want to make your own, go download the hundreds if not thousands of custom maps out there. They STILL WORK with this HD version (i just tested)

Now, there's really only one major thing this game needs, steamworks workshop. I TRUELY believe that if this game had a workshop, for people to show and make available their maps they make, it would be immensely better. Though considering previous maps do work and any map maker can put their map out there on some other website, it's not manditory, it would just bring things together a bit more

reviewText:
Summary:
The product description was clear and explicit, hence I knew what to expect and my expectations were pleasantly met. The Erathia base game is pretty much the same as the Complete eddition, aside from small few things. The most important things missing are: unit hotkeys (most people won't notice), artifact combination (happens rarely anyway), 1 town (the worst one at that, but beautfull), random map generator (not for long, as someone is making one), a few other heroes, and a few units), and obviously the campaign, but that's not why you're getting this game anyway. The multiplayer works well, but you do need to go to Firewall and add exception rule for 3 ports (given in the manual of the game that you can find on steam). Overall, the product is an 8/10.
PRO:
-Most of the stuff works well, the game has slight lag but you probably won't notice it.
-MULTIPLAYER :D
-Price is alright
CON:
-They could have just made the campaign withing a month or 2 tops... (this might come if the game sells well though)
-slight lag, and slight things missing compared to complete eddition is a slight pain point
-MULTIPLAYER: No ladder??? Also, 8 people can join a 4 player game, and the game doesn't always load on first or even 2nd try... Given that I run powerful rig with fast internet, next to the servers, i shouldn't be experiencing problems, hence we can tell that the problems stem from the poor software or servers (probably software..., duh...)
-No replay function, nothing new what so ever.... THe graphics look slightly improved, but I'd rather see stable multiplayer and a rehall of the game without changing any of the gameplay features...
DESCISION:
Buy if you enjoy multiplayer with random people. DO NOT buy if you're expecting it to be perfect or if you're not a fan of HoMM 3 series because this is not a good representation of the potential that this game carries.

reviewText:
*Edit*

I feel it would be dishonest not to mention that I eventually (like a year later) purchased the GOG version of the game along with Hereos Chronicles. It is not because this was a bad HD touch-up. It is due to me wanting to play Hereos but, since I was kind of alone on it, I needed the campaigns to have some fun. This version really has no campaigns to work with so I went with the GOG version and played a ton of that.

Side note: Hereos Chronicles is fantastic. I absolutely love this series. They are a little bit easier than I would like, but the story is just oozing charm. They are also quite long! GET THESE.

I stand by that this was a good HD remake. The sprite touch-ups are wonderful. However, if you play strategy games solo, you might just want to go for the GOG version. IF you do.... check out Chronicles! I wish I could buy that lot again.

*Edit Over*

I loved this game. I loved it all my life. When I was a little child up to right now, I have been playing this game for decades. When I saw this was coming to steam, I bought it instantly. For those who say blah blah go to gog and buy it there and better..."
date: sure... you go buy it there. I want it here on steam
recommended: so I can play with my friends

reviewText:
Heroes of Might & Magic III was pretty much my childhood, I spent countless hours in that game.
This new HD remake is absolutely fantastic, it's a shame it doesn't include the two expansion packs but it was explained why on their website for Heroes VII. Now I can enjoy Heroes III with a pretty new skin and without the distortion that you get when playing the original on HD screens.
Fantastic game, it is (In every aspect other than the uplifted artwork) exactly the same as the original and therefore just as fun. If you liked the original there is no possible way that you could not like this (Unless you're a whiny prick who doesn't appreciate what's here and only concentrates on the two expansions that are not present. Like 99% of the reviews)
Would absolutely recommend.
voteText: 6 of 35 people (17%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Ahh I remember the sweet days where I would sit for hours on end playing Homam with my friends, my brothers and even my dad once in a while. This is truly a nostalgic trip.

Now let us go to this HD Remake.
Now tomorrow me and my friend is going to play this non stop trough the whole night but I played just for 10 minutes to see that everything was working so on.

My reaction is.
What did you expect seriously atleast 60% of the negative reviews are mad because they did not get the expansion pack.  So to clearify you buy the original Heroes of might and magic 3 in HD nothign more nothing less.

Now when we get that out the way time for pros and cons!
Pros:
- Very strategic and it allows for countless of strategic movements
- Becomes smother in HD
- Fun multiplayer
- Fun singleplayer campaign.
- Has the same feelig as the original game
- NO MORE HAMACHI!!!!!

Cons:
- Multiplayer and single player matches restricted to scenarios (aka you need to play on preset maps with preset amount of players) Ps: Crimson clover I highly recommend.
- Multiplayer = you need friends to play with (might work with Steam but in the original it was boring to play against random opponents)

Half Cons: (Things not included in the orignal game but they could have done now):
- Expansions (probably they will come)
- Non scenario Multi and single player
- The lobby music to the game is as in the orignal one far to loud so you have to go into the mixer and change it because you can not change that stuff unless you are in a a game otherwise.


In all and all. It was the game I payed for. It would have been nice if they would have done something extra for the return of the hd remake but I can not be to cranky about it.
8/10 (10/10 if you include my nostalgic rush that feels like I am on crack)

Buy the game!

reviewText: First rule of preordering any game (everyone should know this by now) RESEARCH THE GAME BEFORE YOU PREORDER IT! Because I did my research I knew going into this that the expansions (seriously, DLC was not a thing in the 90s, they are called expansions folks) are NOT included in this release. This includes the bonus faction, minor rule changes (moats doing damage for example) as well as the random map generator.\n\nAll of that said, I got exactly what I paid for: an HD remake of the classic HoMM3. I'd like to eventually get the expansions for this version and will gladly pay for them if they are released as dlc anytime in the future. Till then I am perfectly happy reliving my memories of when I bought this game for my old Pentium 2 machine back in 99 when it came out. Yes, I do recommend this if you're looking for only the base game. If you want everything and the updated graphics aren't important to you then I'd recommend going to gog.com and getting their version that does include everything the original release had plus the expansions.

reviewText:
Shame on the people who are giving this game a negative review.  If anything, why not give it a positive review?  Have more buyers come...  Get them to love the game, just as we (at least, I hope we...) all do.  This is a game of epic proportions.  It is what defined the Turn-Based Strategy Game genre, setting a benchmark that even the creators of this game could not compete with.  This ALSO goes for Ubisoft.

Anyways.... Countless hours have been lost on this game.  It is a masterpiece.  The atmospheric, mood setting music is amongst one of the greatest soundtracks of all time.  Each song matches the scenario, or faction.  The action is immense, with key spells, strategic placement and utilization of units allowing you to sweep a Shadow of Death across the land (ho-ho), and powerful artifacts shape your hero into the god that they will eventually become.

Please buy this game.  Should you have a love for turn based games, strategy games, or simply fantasy games... This is one that will stay in your heart for years, just as this game has done to me for over 14 years.

Cheers.  10/10, hands down one of my favourite games of all time.

reviewText:
Updated:
My experience with the game so far:
The game runs very smooth on my system.
Multiplayer working without any problems.
Not experiencing any mouse stuttering, though some people do.
The game looks beautiful and it has the same feel the original game had back in 1999.
The steam achievements could have been better, disappointment here.

Finally after 15 years of waiting, Heroes 3 is back in action!
Looking forward to see the revival of this game with HD graphics.
Now I can enjoy the game i spent so many hours on without having to tear my eyes out afterwards due to the outdated graphics in the original version of the game.
Most of all, we will finally have a working multiplayer and a map editor that supports the old user made maps from the original game!

This is the most anticipated game for me to be released the last 10 years. Enjoy!

reviewText:
I got home after eight hours of college today. I thought I was going to get a bunch of homework done.

Then I found out that H3HD had been released.

Never had I been so wrong.

(The serious part)
Yes, this is ONLY the Restoration of Erathia. This is only the first release of Heroes of Might and Magic 3. I bought it knowing that the expansions (Shadow of Death and Armageddeon's Blade) were not included. The game plays the same as the Heroes of Might and Magic 3: Restoration of Erathia. It is the same game that I played in 1999, 16ish years ago.

In my honest opinion, I was really excited to see it remade. I am glad to see studios update the graphics and multiplayer capabilities of a classic game that I loved.
voteText: 56 of 214 people (26%) found this review helpful 28 people found this review funny

reviewText:
It is Restoration of Erathia. It was only advertised as Restoration of Erathia. Only the base game.

It is missing a considerable amount of content due to not coming with the expansions, which Ubi/DotEmu warned of since the  first announcement. It is missing a random map generator, and  a whole lot of nice things. Such as the Conflux faction.

But it is still Heroes 3. It is still a FANTASTIC game. It still looks like ♥♥♥, but it is painted-over ♥♥♥. It still has the bad art direction that the original version had.

It does not have all the content the GOG version has. But it is still a fantastic title. It is still Heroes 3, and thus it is still a hell of a game. I hope that  this  (or the tablet versions) lead to more people discovering this absolutely fantastic title.
I mean, it does look a little bit shinier. If you squint.

It is an older game so the graphics were top of the line are now still pretty cool but no longer the top. The detail and design is perfect for the game itself. There are campaigns or the opportunity for multiplayer. It has fantasy and strategy, castle building and hero training. Perfect for those who like a challange.

reviewText: Half Done edition of HoMM 3. One of the worst remakes ive played. If you want to pay money for extra resolutions, go for it. Otherwise, no. No no no. I mean its a great game period. But you just cant take it up a notch and call it a hd edition. The game shouldnt lag on a skylake i5 with gtx 970. And it shouldnt crash randomly, nor have stupid bugs, like most of the texts ingame are unreadable from time to time. At least the editor works. Sure is fun to create scenarios, but i would love to play them properly. Oh, and no extra content whatsoever.

reviewText: I have loved the Might and Magic series since I was 6 and when I saw this game for sale, I knew I had to get it. The graphics, as you can see, are butt ugly. But the gameplay is amazing. It;s probably not worth the 15 bucks it normally is on for, but get it for a good price and let yourself be entertained for hours.

reviewText: I believe that this game is amazing and has honestly one of the best. I prefer the antique design, although you could just get the original for half the price, you are slightly missing out on other things if you do. I do believe the multi-player is a pain to do and I haven't actually played multi-player yet, however that could be due to the complexity of setting it up and what-not, or that people don't play it at all, but that could do with some improvement...\n\nOverall, the best in series, for me personally, and thoroughly recommend it.

reviewText: This game is a game from my childhood and I always enjoyed it very much. It's tactical, interesting with a lot of things to do, monsters of all kinds, huge maps and fierce enemies depending on the difficulty level you choose, etc! More importantly you can play with friends as allies or enemies and I find this really really cool~ the campagns are also quite hard to complete, which is a good challenge for anyone who's determined to finish the game entirely!\n\nI also love the little quests in every scenarios and so on. Great game! ♥

reviewText: I got this game for free with some other game and at first I was impressed with the improved visuals. Then I realized that this is just the base heroes 3 game without any of the expansions. No new features or even keybindings and no conflux castle or extra campaigns or random map generator. Go on gog.com and get heroes 3 complete if you want to play it.
